channel.title: My Halloween '10 Costume
channel.description:
Some of my friends have mentioned that I bear a passing resemblance to Gordon Freeman, and I'd like to see if I can put together an HEV suit for next Halloween, or maybe a convention or the like.
Anyone have any useful suggestions on how I could make a convincing hazard suit on a limited budget?

item.title: My Halloween '10 Costume
item.dc:creator: buttlord
item.description:
youre hairline is the only freeman in ya cuz its gettin away

Read full topic

item.title: My Halloween '10 Costume
item.dc:creator: LonePaladin
item.description:
Yeah, this is the sort of advice I was looking for. Well, except for zim’s, but I expected responses like that. I mean, really, I posted this on the BMS forums, it was bound to happen.

I’ve never tried the papercraft stuff, but then again I’ve never tried any sort of crafting like this at all. As for underneath, I’m thinking maybe some sort of black jumpsuit-style thing or maybe something crocheted in gray thread (for that sorta-chainmail look that some pics show).

And I DID say that I have a ‘passing resemblance’, not that I’m a perfect look-alike. For one, I’m probably about 10 years older – they never mention his age, but I’m guessing mid-20s – so my hairline’s receded somewhat. I’d also have to get a proper pair of glasses for the look; the ones I have don’t quite match up.

If you want to judge for yourself, here’s a picture of me. I know it’s not a perfect match, but it’s a much closer one than that of any of my friends, and they’re the ones who originally mentioned the resemblance.

Again, thanks for the tips, guys. If you find anything else that might be useful for me to gather over the coming year, let me know.

Read full topic

'specially considering every person’s arm/leg structure is different.
BTW if you go the papercraft route, you MAY want to wear something underneath. From experience, paper tends to chafe quickly.

item.title: My Halloween '10 Costume
item.dc:creator: Dias
item.description:
Papercraft templates are easy to make, but a bit harder to make well. You take the model you want and convert it to (OBJ, DXF, MQO, 3DS, LWO, STL, KML, KMZ or DAE) format and import them into Pepakura Designer, rescale it, then print it. It would be a truckload of pages, so it would be better to edit the model into multiple suit part models, removing the fabric textured polys. Also, set the texture in Pepakura to wireframe without texture so it doesn’t use up all the ink. From there it could be a good idea to reinforce the inside of the paper with cardboard or something similar.

Read full topic
